comment.author: 61849735@N00
comment._content: Those clothes are lovely but so glad I don't have to wear them.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Camilla Beach, wife of Frederick O. Beach. NYT of April 9, 1912, has them in the news: "SAY F.O. BEACH ATTACKED WIFE; Intent to Kill Charged at Aiken, S.C., in Warrant for Wealthy New Yorker." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D00E6D6143CE633A... Fodder for a soap opera. NYT of Feb 13, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0DE7DC133BE633A... indicates that he was found not guilty.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of November 29, 1899 reports on their wedding: "FRED. O. BEACH'S BRIDE; Mrs. Charles F. Havemeyer Married to the Popular Clubman. CEREMONY AT GRACE CHURCH. Only a Few Intimate Friends and Relatives Present--Wedding Tour to Europe." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E0CE6D8173DE433A... She was the widow of Charles F Havemeyer. Her maiden name was Camilla Moss. Havemeyer had apparently committed suicide in May 1898. See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9405E5DA143CE433A... Definitely a soap opera!

comment.author: 34876228@N04
comment._content: Thank you for the additional identification. We'll add her name to the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 9276793@N04
comment._content: At first glance I thought the one on the left was on a cell phone, lol.

comment.author: 62690595@N05
comment._content: I researched this case many years ago -- starting from old family tales told in Aiken about it.  I even had the chance to interview the only witness to the assault.  It is one very twisted story with rich folks getting away with the justice they purchased.
